question: What is R-value in insulation, and which insulation materials are commonly used in homes?
generated_answer: R-value in insulation is a measure of the material's resistance to heat flow, indicating its effectiveness as an insulator. The higher the R-value, the better the insulation. Common insulation materials used in homes include fiberglass batts, cellulose, spray foam (both open and closed cell), mineral wool, cotton batts, and blown-in insulation. Each material has its own R-value per inch of thickness, and the choice of insulation depends on factors such as climate, type of home, and specific areas to be insulated.
ground_truth_answer: R-value measures a material's ability to resist heat flow - the higher the R-value, the better the material insulates. It indicates how well a material resists heat transfer when temperatures differ on each side. The thickness and density of the material affect its R-value. Common insulation materials in homes include fiberglass (available as batts, rolls, and loose-fill), cellulose (which can be loose-fill or blown-in), and foam insulation (including spray foam and injection foam). These materials became popular at different times - fiberglass was invented in the 1930s, cellulose became popular in the 1950s, and foam insulation emerged in the 1970s.
